label: TOUR OF THE GLEE CLUB PROVES A HUGE SUCCESS

resource.chars:
TOUR OF THE GLEE CLUB
PROVES A HUGE SUCCESS

The thirty members of the Glee
Club who toured the Eastern Shore
are back. The tour was a success
from the start (discounting, of
course, the fact that all the water
was blown out of the bay so that
the boats couldn’t run, making it
necessary to hire a bus to make the
first engagement on time).
The itinerary, teak in Chester-
town, Dover, Salisbury, Pocomoke,
Crisfleld, Princess Anne, Federals-
burg, and St. Michaels. The week
end of January 2-3 was spent in
Crisfleld where the Club sang in the
Asbury M. E. Church at two serv-
ices Sunday. Last Thursday night,
at a meeting of the Maryland Farm
Bureau Association in the Hotel
Rennert, in Baltimore, music was
furnished by the Club and Orches-
tra as a finale to the trip.

Everywhere appreciative audien-
ces made known their delight and
satisfaction in the clean, spicy, and
varied program that was rendered.
Dr. Hale, Prof. Goodyear, Barron,
Pyles and M. P. Johnson acquitted
themselves nobly every time the
program was repeated, and each
was called upon to report to many
encores.
Of course, tliere was the usual
amount of delays, forgetting, hus-
tle and bustle throughout the trip.
Some of the members are likely to
hang out a piano-mover’s shingle,
notable among them Strong Arm
(T. W.) Johnson.
Van Sickler joined the Club at
Princess Anne, as he had been ill
the previous ten days. However,
up to that time Dr. House whipped
M. P. Johnson into such good shape
that no one knew he was not the
regular pianist.
Dr. House said the Club did ex-
cellent work throughout the trip.
U. of M.
